genre_as_recorded: Manuscripts, Persian--Iran--Shīrāz--16th century|Miniatures (Illuminations)--Iran--Shīrāz--16th century|Headpieces (layout features)--Iran--Shīrāz--16th century|Illuminated manuscripts--Iran--Shīrāz--16th century|Poetry
physical_description: Extent: 475 leaves : paper, col. ill. ; 476 x 335 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Text begins on fol. 12b.|Includes 51 miniatures; handlist of their description by Louise Marlow on file.|Physical description: 29 lines per page, in four columns; written in nastaʻliq on glazed paper. Volume measures 47.6 x 33.5 cm; written surface, 30 x 16.5 cm. Catchwords; some marginal notations. Some leaves have been repaired at edges. In excellent condition.|Decoration: Text framed in silver, red, gold, black and orange; columns separated by gold bands containing floral pattern. Text on gilt is in white; some marginal notes in red. Illuminated caption bands throughout text. Title page, following page and first page of text are elaborately illuminated. 51 miniatures by an artist of the Shīrāz school illustrate famous events of the epic. Six of these appear on opposing pages at the beginning, middle (222b-223a) and end. The margins are illuminated with gilt floral and animal motifs.|Origin: Copied by Qiwām ibn Muḥammad Shīrāzī in 998 H [1589 or 90] (fol. 474a); likely produced in Shīrāz.|Inscription of ownership on f. 475b of Khayrāt Khān, envoy from ʻAbd Allāh Quṭbshāh to Iṣfahān, who purchased the ms. from the daughter of Khān Aḥmad Khān of Gīlān and widow of Shāh ʻAbbās in Rajab 1040H (February 1631). The ms. was later owned by Sir George Holford, equerry to George V, and likely purchased by A. S. W. Rosenbach in 1925. The ms. was subsequently sold to Clara Peck by Rosenbach in 1946 (Marlow, 214).

Rubrication and catchwords. Headings in large naskh in red; Arabic quotations in large naskh in black, vocalized, and overlined in red. Title and volume in large, red naskh at top of each page. Topics at top of page and outer margins in large, red naskh. Foliated in Arabic script in red on verso of each folio, with numerous mistakes; some of the foliation is missing due to water damage. Inserts between fol. 226-227, 375-376. Fol. 444a-445a, 446a blank. Water damage has caused paper loss around the edges, but text unaffected. Occasional smudging and foxing. Holograph.|Origin: According to first colophon on fol. 440a, the text was completed in 1269 H. [1852 or 3] in the village of Tajrīsh in the township of Shamīrān on the outskirts of Tehran. In the second colophon the author states that he completed this copy from the first draft on the last day of Dhū al-Ḥijjah 1278 H. [28 June 1862]; this note is accompanied by two stamps of the author dated 1278 H.|Author's stamp on fol. 1b and owner's stamps on fol. 446b.

Light smudging and staining, and a few paper repairs to the inner margins. Incomplete at beginning and end.|Decoration: Small, somewhat amateurish, illuminated ʻunwān on fol. 1a in gold, blue, and maroon. On fol. 13b-14a are minatures which have been pasted onto the pages at a later date, likely late 19th century. The first shows a man being hung by four men. The second shows a supplicant kneeling before a king on a second storey while a woman brings a small cow up a ladder; on the first floor two men are conversing.|Decoration: The front doublure consists of a sheet of pink paper with gold floral decoration pasted onto a larger sheet of blue paper with black and gold framing. The writing, in shikastah, is likely in the hand of Ḥasan ʻAlī Khān Garrūsī, a well-known civil servant, penman, and calligrapher [1821?-1900]. The back doublure consists of a sheet of white paper pasted onto a larger sheet of yellow paper with black flecking and black and gold framing. The writing, in shikastah, is likely of the school of Qāʼim Maqām, rhetorician and statesman [1779 or 80-1835].

Sūrah headings written in white on gold ground filled with a floral pattern and set within a rectangle framed in blue. Otherwise in excellent condition.|Decorations: Sunburst ornament on fol. 1a enclosing medallions inscribed with the volume's contents. Well-executed illuminated ʻunwāns at the beginning of each poem, in gold and colors. Illustrated with eight full-page miniatures in the classical Persian style, executed in the early 20th century; the signature on fol. 54b of Turābī Bek Khurāsānī is likely a nom de plume.|Origin: Copy completed by ʻAlī al-Ḥusaynī al-kātib in the middle of Rabīʻ II 930 [February 1524] in Harāt (fol. 186b).

genre_as_recorded: Manuscripts, Persian--17th century|Headpieces (layout features)--Islamic countries--17th century|Illuminated manuscripts--Islamic countries--17th century|Miniatures (Illuminations)--Islamic countries--17th century|Lacquered bindings--Islamic countries--19th century|Poetry
physical_description: Extent: i, 357 leaves: paper, col. ill. ; 273 x 181 (190 x 123) mm. bound to 284 x 187 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1b.|Physical description: 19 lines per page, in four columns; written in small, elegant nastaʻliq in black on glazed, laid Arabic paper. Prefaces and poem 1 on blue paper, poem 2 on white, poem 3 on salmon, poem 4 on green, and poem 5 on indigo. Text bordered by blue and gold lines, with outer marginal gold line; columns separated by double gold lines. Text occasionally written on a diagonal. Catchwords. Fol. 234-5, 288, 329-30, 344, 34, 353-357 have been mounted on thin machine-made paper. Some paper repairs and marginal damp staining. Otherwise in good condition.|Decoration: Elaborately illuminated ʻunwāns in gold and colors mark the two prefaces and each poem; titles in white on gold ground. On fol. 7b-8a, text embellished with floral pattern in gold and color, and margins decorated with gold and color foliar pattern. Text on first two pages of remaining poems set within clouds on gold ground. Headings in white on gold ground decorated with floral pattern. Similar pattern in gold and color is used to fill spaces around diagonal text.|Decoration: Thirty-five miniatures of good quality from the same period as the ms. Two are full-page (fol. 6b-7a) and are set within gold, maroon, blue, and orange frames with margins decorated with gold floral pattern. The first miniature is signed Raqam-i [...] ʻAlī-Riḍā ʻAbbāsī sanah 1[0]82 H [?].|Origin: Prefaces written in Rabīʻ I 1054 H [April 1644] (fol. 3a); copy completed around same time. Original text completed 206 years prior (fol. 2b), i.e. 848 H [1444 or 5].|Two owner's stamps at the end and beginning of each poem. Acquired from Kalebdjian Frères, 1926.

physical_description: Extent: 451 leaves : paper, col. ill. ; 148 x 237 (85-90 x 155-162) mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Physical description: 17 lines per page; written in beautiful nastaʻliq in black on glazed, laid Arabic paper. Catchwords. Headings in gold, blue, and red. Text framed in gold, red, and black.|Decoration: Ms. contains twelve miniatures from the beginning of the 16th century by Bihzād. Fol. 1, 2, and the miniature pages elaborately illuminated in gold and color.|Origin: Copied in 872 H [1467 or 8] by Shīr ʻAlī.|From the inscription in the center of the medallion on the front page, this ms. was deposited in the treasury of Sultan Ḥusayn Bahādur, 1506, for whom Bihzād probably painted the miniatures. According to a note immediately below the colophon, the ms. was presented by Mīr Jamāl al-Dīn Ḥusayn Inju to the Mogul Emperor Akbar (r. 1556-1605). Gift of Robert Garrett (Class of 1897) in January 1942; subsequently sold by the Trustees to John Work Garrett in February 1942, who later gifted the ms. to Johns Hopkins University.

Some staining, smudging, and insect damage (particularly towards the end of the ms.). First and last few leaves repaired, mostly around margins; these leaves are also heavily worn and in poor condition.|Decoration: Two-page ʻunwān on fol. 1b-2a; title inscribed in gold in Kufic-type script in illuminated boxes above and below text on both pages; margins decorated with gold and color floral pattern. Most of the color has worn off. Jild 2-4 (fol. 89b, 169b, 277a) are marked by an ʻunwān consisting of an illuminated rectangular box with the jild number inscribed in gold in Kufic-type script, and the margins are illuminated with gold and color floral pattern, similarly to the opening pages. Jild 5-6 (fol. 360a, 455a) have the same marginal illumination, but their ʻunwāns have much simpler embellishments; jild 6 is written in black naskh and jild 5 is unmarked. Fol. 491b-492a have illuminated margins and the ʻunwān has been covered with gold; likely these pages were illuminated by mistake. Small floral illumination around colophon on fol. 568a.|Origin: Jild 1 completed 28 Dhū al-Qaʻdah 879 H [5 April 1475] by Yaḥyá ibn Manṣūr ibn Muḥammad al-Ḥasanī al-Ḥusaynī al-Mūsavī (fol. 89b). Jild 2 completed 12 Rabīʻ I 88[0] H [16 July 1475] (fol. 169b). Jild 3 completed 26 Shawwāl 881 H [11 February 1477] by the same scribe (fol. 276b). Jild 4 completed 15 Jumādá 1 886 H [12 July 1481] (fol. 359b). Remainder completed in 896 H [1490 or 91] by Masʻūd ibn Yaḥyá ibn Manṣūr al-Ḥasanī al-Ḥusaynī (fol. 568a).|The date 1275 H [1858 or 9] is noted on fol. 1a. The date 1310 H [1892 or 3] is noted after the colophon on fol. 568a. On fol. ib: notes dated 1300 H [1882 or 3] and 27 Ṣafar 1340 H [30 October 1921].

Text bordered by gold and blue with outer marginal gold line on fol. 1b-2a, 250b-251a. Remainder of text bordered by two red lines with central blue line and outer marginal blue line. physical_description: Extent: 241 leaves : paper ; 295 x 190 (205 x 125) mm. bound to 300 x 195 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from colophon, fol. 241b.|On front cover: Label reading "318" in Arabic script.|Physical description: 20 lines per page; written in nastaʻliq in black on glazed, laid European paper. Rubrication and catchwords. Arabic quotations overlined in red. Paginated in Arabic script 1-485 beginning on fol. 1b. Modern printed insert after last folio gives the ancestry and dates of birth and death of Mahdī Muṭahhariyān, likely a former owner, along with his picture.|Origin: Copy completed by Muṣṭafá Qulī Sulṭān, 14 Muḥarram 1257 H. [8 March 1841] (fol. 241b). However, a note following the colophon by the same scribe corrects the year to 1258 H. [25 February 1842].|Stamps of four different owners on fol. 1a, the most recent being three of Sayyid Nūr al-Dīn Muṭahhariyān (likely the same as the person mentioned in the insert, Mahdī Muṭahhariyān, who was born 13 Rajab 1294 H. [24 July 1877] and died 12 Dhū al-Ḥijjah 1377 H. [30 June 1958]). Given as a waqf by Sayyid Muḥammad Riz̤ā Muṭahhariyān (fol. 1a, 241b), who is the author of the insert. Ownership stamp of Nūr al-Dīn Muṭahhariyān and waqf stamp on other pages throughout the ms.

Inserts in vol. 2 before fol. 1 and between fol. 87-88. subject_as_recorded: Manuscripts, Persian--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 414 leaves : paper ; 233 x 129 (187 x 96) mm. bound to 242 x 144 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1b.|On front cover: Label reading "30" in Arabic script.|On spine: Label reading "808" in Arabic script. Tooled in gold in Arabic script: "Kullīyāt-i Shaykh Saʻdī" and "Kitābkhānah-i R. Ṣamṣāmī."|Physical description: 20 lines per page, in 1-2 columns; written in nastaʻliq in black on glazed, laid Arabic paper.Text area framed in blue and gold and divided into a central area and an outer column; text begins in center box, then continues in outer column and is written on the diagonal. Columns delineated by double gold lines. Catchwords and some marginal notes. Ms. is divided into seven books paginated in Arabic script as follows (first two pages of Books 1-5 unpaginated): Book 1, 3-62; Book 2, 3-118; Book 3, 3-168; Book 4, 3-93 (last page unnumbered); Book 5, 3-168; Book 6, 1-76; Book 7, 1-86 (last 51 pages unnumbered). Extensive damp staining in lower half of text block, but text largely unaffected. Repairs to leaves at beginning and end of text block, mostly to the inner margin.|Decoration: Books 1-5 begin with an elegant two-page illumination consisting of an ʻunwān and decorations within the text frame and in the margins. The ʻunwān is painted mainly in gold, dark blue, purple, and orange in a delicate floral design and is divided into two boxes, the lower of which contains the title in white set within a mandorla-shaped gold background. Each ʻunwān features a slightly different style of decoration. The text area is framed with blue and gold while the background is illuminated with gold and the text is set within white clouds; the columns are delineated by thick dark blue and purple lines in which are painted a white foliar design. The outer column is written on the diagonal and extra space is filled in with delicate multi-colored floral designs. The margins are filled with a gold foliar pattern. The illumination for Book 1 is somewhat damaged as the paper is repaired around the margins, while the ʻunwān for Book 5 is smudged at the top. Books 6-7 begin with a simple ʻunwān in gold, blue, and orange in which the title is written in white within a large gold box.|Origin: Ms. completed in parts. Book 2 completed Dhū al-Ḥijjah 1045 H. [May or June 1636] (fol. 91a). Book 3 completed 1051 H. [1641 or 2] (fol. 175a). Book 4 completed Ṣafar 1051 H. [May or June 1641] (fol. 222a). Book 7 completed Jumādá I 1107 [?] [December 1695 or January 1696] (fol. 411b).|Owner's note and stamps on fol. 1a dated 127[-] H. Owner's note of Bāqir Khān, 1215 H. [1800 or 1801] and smudged owner's stamp on fol. 411b.

Also on the verso of the front endpaper is the following statement: "Presented to Samuel Bochart the Celebrated Traveller and Linguist 22nd July MDCXLVIII (1648) by Ce Sarravius." However, all four fragments and the binding appear more recent than this date.

physical_description: Extent: 55 leaves : paper, col. ill. ; 485 x 280 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|The album consists of 55 folios measuring 485 x 280 mm.|Origin: The signed paintings and calligraphies are attributed to Mīr ʻAlī, Sulṭān ʻAlī al-Mashhadī, Muḥammad ʻAẓīm al-Ikthīr, ʻImād al-Ḥusaynī, Muḥammad Muʻīn ʻAlī Tajallī (= Shāh Muḥammad Muʻīn ʻAlī Tajallī Chishtī, fol. 32a), Muḥammad Ibrāhīm, ʻAbd Allāh, Muḥammad ʻAlī, Muḥammad Badīʻ al-Iṣfahānī, Tajallī ʻAlī Shāh, Muḥammad Karīm, Anūp Chator (Chatar, Chitor: see Titley), Mīr Muḥammad Māh Ḥusaynī, Zayn al-Ḥaqq, Zarrīn Raqam, Muḥammad Afḍal, Ghulām Muṣṭafá Khān, Muḥammad Aṭhar, Asad Allāh, Mughalkhān, Ghulām Jamāl Allāh Khān, Sayyid ʻAlī Būkhārī Rūshan Raqam, Jawāhir Raqam-i Thānī, Muḥammad Ḥusayn, Muḥammad ʻAlī Gawhar, Muḥammad al-Fakhkhār, Abū al-Baqāʼ al-Mūsawī, Kifāyat Khān, Ismāʻīl, Ilyās Bahādur, Aḥmad Shāh, Muḥammad Dalīr, and date from 1014H. [1630 or 31] to 1189 [1775]. Other undated paintings can be dated to 18th-19th century India and 16th or early 17th century Central Asia. One piece is dated Awrangābād, [1]203 [1788 or 9] (fol. 22a).|A letter attached to the album mentions that this was made for the Portuguese governor of India, but this is a late attribution. The document further indicates that the book belonged to the Delaney family who sold it to Sir John Malcolm (1769-1833) from the East India Company. It was then sold to Rowland Jones Esq. (1772-1856), Broom Hall, Carnarvonshire, Wales. The album was then auctioned in an estate sale between Feb. 24 and March 8, 1857 at Carnarvonshire and was purchased by William Stewart Esq. (1798-1874) of Aldenham Abbey, Hertfordshire. Stewart sold the book at Christie's auction in London in 1875. There was probably another owner after Stewart from whom Robert Garrett (1875-1961) purchased the album.

physical_description: Extent: 244 leaves: paper, col. ill. ; 340 X 240 (268 x 150) mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 3a.|Physical description: 20 lines to the page ; written in nastaʻlīq, in black ink with use of red. Cream paper, glossy, with laid lines and fiber visible. Margins of most leaves repaired. The text is framed within a medium large gold line outlined in black, with a blue outline on the outer edge (faded on several leaves). The miniatures are framed in one medium large gold line outline in black ; some miniatures go over the text frame (see e.g. fol. 9b, 87b, 193a, 236b). One small miniature on the margin (the deer on fol. 237b). Occasional lines of poetry and annotations written by another hand on the margins (see fol. 197b, 227b-228a). Dampness damage (stains, ink transfer from one page to the next), with loss of text. Modern foliation in pencil (blank after fol. 116, 179, 229).|Decoration: Illuminated title page executed in opaque watercolors, ink, and gilt (fol. 1a); margins of fol. 1b-2a decorated with flowers in gold. The same floral motif appears on the sides of the colophon (fol. 240a).|Decoration: Contains 165 miniatures in opaque watercolors and ink, representing planets (fol. 14b-18b), constellations such as Cassiopea (fol. 21b), inhabitants of exotic and fabulous islands, such as the inhabitants of Sumatra (fol. 56b) and of Wāqwāq (fol. 56b), fabulous animals, and monsters (see fol. 9b, 69b, 189b), Archangels (fol. 32b-34a), and various plants (fol. 107b on) and animals (fol. 196b on). Most miniatures are executed on a blue or gold sky, with Chinese clouds, with mountain or rocks behind which animals or human figures appear ; streams and trees are other common motifs.|Decoration: Contains diagrams in gold and red.|Origin: The copy (or the text?) is dated Ṣafar 895 [1489] or 865 [1460] and signed ʻAbd Allāh son of ʻAlī Bey Damāvandī in the colophon (fol. 240a). According to Moghadam, illustrations and binding probably from 18th century India.|Ownership statement after the colophon, in the name of Sayyid Ibrāhīm Ḥusayn ibn al-Sayyid al-Muẓaffar(?), with illegible seal. The same name appears in an ownership statement on fol. 240b, along with several others, some obliterated, one dated Rabīʻ al-Awwal 1238 [Nov.-Dec. 1822]. Small turquoise seal on the upper outer corner of the same leaf. Stamp with the inscription: "Douane centrale française Paris" on a label pasted on fol. 1a.|Several ownership statements, the oldest bearing the date 1168 H.

On fol. 116a, 138b, seal and notes of ʻAbd Naṣr Allāh, the former dated Ṣafar 1274 H [September-October 1857].

genre_as_recorded: Miniatures (Illuminations)--India--18th century|Headpieces (layout features)--India--18th century|Illuminated manuscripts--India--18th century|Manuscripts, Persian--18th century
physical_description: Extent: 344 leaves : paper, col. ill. ; 323 x 214 (255-269 x 159) mm. bound to 325 x 218 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1b.|Physical description: 25-26 lines per page in four columns; written in nastaʻliq script in black on beige Arabic glazed, laid paper. Introduction on fol. 1b-6a written in one column. Text framed by inner border of red, silver, gold and blue and outer border of gold; columns separated by gold lines. Boxes left for subtitles are not all filled in. Some repairs to leaves with partial loss of header on fol. 1; dampstaining in inner margin on some leaves. In the upper left corner of most leaves a later hand has entered the reigning shāh for that section of the story, though not always correctly.|Decoration: Illuminated ʻunwāns on on fol. 1b, 6b. Contains 34 miniatures as follows:|1. fol. 9b: Ṭahmuras̲ slays the black dīv.|2. fol. 11a: Jamshīd enthroned.|3. fol. 11b: Faraydūn enthroned.|4. fol. 13a: Z̤aḥḥāk receiving men. He is depicted with the heads of two black snakes on either shoulder.|5. fol. 13b: The daughter of Gūrang receives the prophecy that she will marry Jamshīd and give birth to a warrior son.|6. fol. 20b: The daughter of Gūrang gives birth to Garshāsp.|7. fol. 24a: Z̤aḥḥāk and his men ride off to war. The two snakes on Z̤aḥḥāk's shoulders have human heads.|8. fol. 25a: Faraydūn binds Z̤aḥḥāk upside-down in a cave.|9. fol. 25b: Faraydūn feasting after the victory.|10. fol. 26b: Faraydūn and Garshāsp.|11. fol. 29b: Garshāsp fighting.|12. fol. 31b: The battle between the Iranians and the Turanians.|13. fol. 38a: Prisoners of war after battle.|14. fol. 40b: King of Yemen with his three daughters and the three sons of Faraydūn.|15. fol. 44a: Salm slays Īraj.|16. fol. 48a: The battle between Manūchihr and Tūr.|17. fol. 49b: The battle between Manūchihr and Salm.|18. fol. 50a: Manūchihr killing Salm.|19. fol. 52a: The birth of Zāl.|20. fol. 67b: The meeting of Zāl and Rudābah.|21. fol. 68b: Zāl and his father Sām.|22. fol. 88a: Rustām slays the white dīv.|23. fol. 109a: Rustām and Suhrāb duel one another. Rustām is depicted wearing a leopard hat in this miniature and the ones that follow.|24. fol. 109b: The death of Suhrāb.|25. fol. 126b: Afrāsiyāb, king of Tūrān, and his court.|26. fol. 129a: Siyāvash and Farangīs, daughter of Afrāsiyāb.|27. fol. 139a: The death of Siyāvash.|28. fol. 140a: The birth of Kay Khusraw.|29. fol. 142b: Kay Khusraw on his throne.|30. fol. 157b: Rustām sits before Kay Khusraw.|31. fol. 180a: Kay Kāvus on his throne.|32. fol. 187a: Rustām slays Ashkabus with mace.|33. fol. 188b: Rustām's fight with the Turanians.|34. fol. 338a: The camp of Iskandar.|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1904, from the books of Amīn ibn Ḥasan al-Ḥulwānī al-Madanī al-Ḥanafī (Medina).

physical_description: Extent: 170 leaves : paper, ill. ; 183 x 110 (149 x 79) mm. bound to 189 x 113 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Physical description: Written in nastaʻliq script in black in a cloud defined by a black line: ground for text plain and the remainder gold. On white European glazed, laid paper. Text and most images bordered by gold, red and pink frame with foliar design. Three layouts for text: 1. Author in red on plain ground with gold and black frame; text in two columns with last two lines centered and flanked by flowers. 2. Text written diagonally in two black frames; remainder of space filled with flowers. 3. Three framed double rows of text in two columns alternating with a single central row of text flanked by flowers. Not all frames are filled. With 101 Mugal-style miniatures.|On pastedown of back cover: Ex libris Harry Glemby.

title_as_recorded: Woman reading on a large stool
physical_description: Extent: 1 painting on paper : watercolor and gilt ; image and text 25 x 18 cm.
note: Image: 15.4 x 9.7 cm.|Mounted: 48.9 x 36.2 cm.|Depicted is a woman in Persian dress sitting outdoors on a large octogonal stool reading a book. Next to her is a dove tied to the stool. The picture is set within a navy and gold frame. Four lines of Persian verse written in nastaʻliq script in black inside gold boxes are set within the navy portion of the frame, one verse per side.|On the verso: Ali Reza Bihzad, possibly the artist?|Undated; possibly from the 18th century?

physical_description: Extent: i, 389, i leaves : paper ; 189 x 137 (125-143 x 75-94) mm. bound to 238 x 133 mm.
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title from fol. 3a.|On spine: Label reading "Y113."|Manuscript erroneously foliated beginning on the front flyleaf. Record follows erroneous numbering.|Physical description: 17-23 lines per page; written in naskh in black on a variety of paper and by different hands. Fol. 2-10 on tan glazed, laid Arabic paper; Arabic words overlined in red and headings in red. Fol. 11-60 on thin glazed, laid European paper, some of it tinted salmon; Arabic words overlined in red and headings in large script. Fol. 61-154 on glazed, laid European paper, some of it tinted yellow; Arabic words overlined in black, Arabic phrases overlined in red, and headings in red. Fol. 155-209 on glazed, laid European paper; Arabic words overlined in red and headings in red. Fol. 210-390 on glazed, laid European paper; Arabic words overlined in red and headings in large script. Catchwords throughout manuscript. First leaf missing. Fol. 209b blank, but no lacuna in text. Marginal water damage and some paper repairs, with no loss of text.|Two owner's stamps on fol. 2a; partially rubbed-out owner's statement and stamp on fol. 389a dated 1052 H. [1642 or 3].|Acquired from Abraham Shalom Yahuda.
